thread.title: Dan DeLuca's Mix Picks: Disclosure, ' A Brief History of Seven Killings,' Daniel Bachman,' Old 97's, 'The Story of the Lost Child'
thread.title_full: Dan DeLuca's Mix Picks: Disclosure, ' A Brief History of Seven Killings,' Daniel Bachman,' Old 97's, 'The Story of the Lost Child'

author: Dan DeLuca,
title: Dan DeLuca's Mix Picks: Disclosure, ' A Brief History of Seven Killings,' Daniel Bachman,' Old 97's, 'The Story of the Lost Child'
text:
Disclosure. Two nights with brothers Guy and Howard Lawrence. The British dance music producers broke out with 2013's Settle, thanks to Sam Smith's singing on "Latch." They're back with the packed-with-pop-stars album Caracal, with Lorde, Miguel, and, again, Smith. The biggest EDM event thus far at the spiffy new Fishtown venue. Monday and Tuesday at the Fillmore.
"A Brief History of Seven Killings," by Marlon James. Jamaican American novelist James deservedly won the prestigious Man Booker literary prize for his multivalent 2014 novel that revolves around the 1976 assassination attempt on Bob Marley. (Riverhead, $17.)
Daniel Bachman. An acoustic and lap steel guitarist in the John Fahey mold whose playing was shaped by his friendship with the late Philadelphia virtuoso Jack Rose. Wednesday at the First Unitarian Church Side Chapel.
Old 97's / Shark Tape. The Rhett Miller-led roots-rock band Old 97's made a raucous and free-spirited return to form with last year's Most Messed Up, and here they're paired with the well-matched rising Philadelphia trio fronted by ace songwriter Stephen Lorek. Thursday at Union Transfer.
More coverage Joe Walsh rocks the Fillmore with a greatest-hits set BÃ˜RNS delivers his dreamy harmonies at Union Transfer Colbert's bandleader Jon Batiste brings his Love Riot to Philly "The Story of the Lost Child," by Elena Ferrante. I don't know what I'm going to do with myself once I finish this novel, the fourth and final installment in the marvelous Neopolitan series about the friendship of two Italian women written by the mysterious Ferrante, who has never given an interview. Start over and reread My Brilliant Friend, the first in the series, I suppose. (Europe, $18.)
